Award.AwardTitle: Facing the Challenges of Vector-Borne Diseases in the 21st Century: Symposium; New Genomics Building at the University of California-Riverside
Award.AbstractNarration:
The field of vector-borne diseases spans the biology and genomics of the arthropod vectors of mammalian and plant disease agents, the microbes and viruses transmitted by insects and ticks, and host responses to vectors and vector-borne diseases. Advances in molecular biology and genomics have created an unprecedented opportunity for deciphering common evolutionary adaptations of vectors and pathogens they transmit. This award will support participation of early-career scientists in the "Facing the Challenges of Vector-Borne Diseases in the 21st Century" symposium at the University of California at Riverside, March 27-28, 2010. The UCR symposium is the first to bring together researchers in the area of vector-borne disease of plants and animals. Seven scientific sessions and two forumswill provide opportunities to discuss cross-disciplinary topics. This meeting will synergize experts from the animal and plant communities, who often do not interact, in order to bring about a greater understanding of the current themes and challenges for the future, providing a new paradigm for meetings in this research area.

Broader Impacts: It is anticipated that by bringing together scientists from the plant and animal disease-vector communities using a range of approaches from molecular genetics, genomics and social sciences, this symposium will enable synergistic interactions and stimulate research innovations and collaborations in these fields. With only 104 participants, the symposium affords researchers, including graduate students and postdoctoral associates, an opportunity for one-on-one discussions and exchanges to an extent that is not usually possible at large professional society meetings. The NSF funds will be used to support the travel of early career investigators including Assistant Professors, postdoctoral fellows and graduate students. Women, underrepresented minority participants, and postdocs and students from the labs of Assistant Professors will be encouraged to participate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant provided funding for a symposium entitled “Facing the Challenges of Vector-Borne Diseases in the 21st Century”. The symposium was developed by faculty in the Center for Disease-Vector Research (CDVR) at the University of California at Riverside (UCR). This two-day symposium was held on March 27-28, 2010. The meeting was proposed because there is

an acute need for a common forum for researchers working on vectors of animal and plant diseases. Advances in molecular biology and genomics have opened up an unprecedented opportunity for deciphering common evolutionary adaptations of arthropod vectors and the pathogens they transmit. Scientists can now address the intriguing question of what makes arthropods such ideal vectors of diseases of plants, humans and animals. The time was right for a focused meeting integrating and highlighting recent achievements in both the plant and animal fields. Yet, despite the obvious benefits of such a meeting for the scientific community of vector biologists and students, to our knowledge this is the first proposed symposium of this kind. Invited speakers for the symposium were chosen to represent various areas at the cutting edge of vector biology of both plants and humans. Seventeen international leaders in the field of plant and animal vector-biology accepted the invitation to speak in this symposium. In addition, fourteen UCR faculty balanced the symposium’s speaker list. Over 52% of the faculty participating in the Symposium were junior scientists at the Assistant or Associate levels. In addition, 58% of the entire symposia participants were graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.

 The aim of this Symposium was to bring together well-established scientists, as well as young investigators who study the biology of the vectors and the pathogens they transmit to plants and animals of agricultural and medical importance. The topics presented in the meeting were focused on the current and future challenges in these fields. This meeting served to synergize experts from the animal and plant communities, who often don’t interact, in order to bring about a greater understanding of the current themes and challenges for the future of vector-borne disease. The meeting also incorporated the social and economic consequences of vector-borne diseases in the developing world with two invited presentations on this topic. The keynote address by Dr. Debas illustrated how an integrated approach to global health challenges (in which vector-borne disease impacts both public health and agriculture) is critical for translational success.  This symposium was a fertile ground for establishing new collaborations and a new paradigm for future meetings in this area of research. The diversity and strengths of UCR’s CDVR provided an ideal template upon which to initiate and build cross-disciplinary communication platform, with the long-term aim being to train both students, postdoctoral fellows and faculty to develop successful strategies for vector control.

 The conference Facing the Challenges of Vector-Borne Diseases in the 21st Century was unique in its scope and audience by bringing together researchers in the fields of plant and animal vector-borne disease and economics. The Symposium integrated the discoveries of plant, animal, and social scientists in ten sessions. The topics included:

  • Keynote lecture: Interdisciplinary Approach to Global Health Challenges in the 21st Century
  • Social impact of vector-borne disease
  • Population Genetics and Systematics of Disease Vectors
  • Host-seeking behavior in Disease Vectors
  • Genetic and Molecular Approaches to Investigation of Vector-Pathogen Interactions I
  • Genetic and Molecular Approaches to Investigation of Vector-Pathogen Interactions II
